awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  The Biocultural Production of Resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

What allows some people to navigate adversity better than others and how can these factors be used to improve human wellbeing? Answers to this question have important implications for an array of disciplines, including anthropology, psychiatry, human development, public health, and disaster management. This doctoral dissertation project aims to provide greater clarity on this matter both to improve broad scientific understanding of human adaptation and to inform policy and programs aimed at the promotion of human wellbeing, especially in the face of hardships that affect people around the globe, such as political instability, economic difficulties, and interpersonal conflict. In addition to providing scientific training for a graduate student, this project is characterized by cooperative international partnerships which both broaden the scientific participation of underrepresented groups and allow for the insights and data produced to go directly into the hands of those who shape policy and programs that impact health.

This doctoral dissertation project examines differences in resilience among mothers and children living in the context of intense political and socioeconomic hardship, comparing outcomes before and after a series of community-wide adverse events. Resilience is best understood as better-than-expected outcomes in the face of adversity. This research seeks to identify the types of resources, both material and abstract, that help women and children more successfully navigate difficult circumstances, as well as explore transgenerational factors that contribute to resilience. A combination of qualitative and quantitative methods will be used to assess changes in the mental and physical health of women and children over time, examine the relationship between maternal and child resilience, and explore the role of varying philosophies of struggle in fostering resilience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The reasons why some individuals are better able to navigate adversity than others are compelling questions for the social, behavioral, and public health sciences. This phenomenon, frequently referred to as resilience, incorporates interactions between human adaptation, psychology, and culture in contexts of adversity. Importantly, a better understanding of these interactions could lead to methods of harm reduction in the face of structural violence, political upheaval, and climate change.

This project provided insight on resilience among women and children living in rural Nicaragua during a sociopolitical crisis and a global pandemic, with larger implications for how we understand resilience among stressed populations. First, it found that greater autonomy among women was associated with psychological resilience, suggesting that those who are interested in promoting resilience in similar communities should focus on women's empowerment initiatives. Second, it contributed to a small, but growing, area of study on idioms of resilience, which are an important part of understanding how people of different backgrounds communicate about resilience. In the case of women in rural Nicaragua, variants of the phrase "seguir adelante"(translated as "to keep going" or "to get ahead") were frequently used to talk about resilience in interviews. In the context of the ethnographic data, the use of this phrase suggests that resilience for these women is about moving past their negative experiences and improving both themselves and their lives through effort.

Additionally, the findings of this project also raise important ethical questions about how anthropologists ought to engage with and write about the concept of resilience, especially when working with marginalized people. Can anthropologists frame findings on resilience research in ways that prevent it from being used as an excuse to not address the larger problems for which resilience is necessary? We hope that this project can open up a larger conversation about ethical ways of doing resilience research.

Finally, this project was able to make positive impacts within the community in which it was conducted. First, during the collection of biological data, nearly one half of the women participating in the study were referred to the local health clinic for early intervention or treatment for diabetes, high blood pressure, or high cholesterol. Routine testing for these problems is often inaccessible in rural Nicaragua, and this project was able to provide a free screening, leading them to seek professional assessment, diagnosis, and treatment before the problems escalated. In terms of psychosocial health, the co-PI received reports from both participants and community health workers that the life history interviews conducted during the spring of 2023 were a fulfilling experience for a large portion of participating women. For some of these women, these life history interviews served as a cathartic outlet and opportunity for self-expression and exploration that they otherwise would not have had. Second, the findings of this project provided feedback on existing programs and guidance for future work by a health-focused NGO that works within Nicaragua and the Dominican Republic. These include insights on the effectiveness of programs for combating food and water insecurity, as well as recommendations for future programs to add components which foster social support networks and women's empowerment.
